contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Olympia oyster | image = Olympia_oyster.jpg | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Mollusca]] | classis = [[Bivalvia]] | ordo = [[Ostreoida]] | familia = [[Ostreidae]] | genus = '''''Ostreola''''' | species = '''''O. conchaphila''''' | binomial = ''Ostreola conchaphila'' | binomial_authority = [[Phillip Pearsall Carpenter|Carpenter]], 1857 }} The '''Olympia oyster''', ''Ostreola conchaphila'', is the native [[oyster]] of the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] coast of [[North America]] from [[Alaska]] to [[Mexico]]. The name is derived from the important 19th-century oyster industry near [[Olympia, Washington]], in [[Puget Sound]]. ==Use by Native Americans== [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] peoples consumed ''O. conchaphila'' everywhere it was found, with consumption in [[San Francisco Bay]] so intense, enormous [[midden]]s of oyster shells were piled over thousands of years. One of the largest such mounds, the [[Emeryville Shellmound]], near the mouth of [[Temescal Creek (Northern California)|Temescal Creek]] and the eastern end of the [[San Francisco â€“ Oakland Bay Bridge]], is now buried under the Bay Street shopping center.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.sacred-sites.org/preservation/shell.html|title=Emeryville Shellmound|publisher=Sacred Sites International Foundation|date=March 1, 2004|accessdate=2010-09-11}}</ref> ==Decline and return in California== ''O. conchaphila'' nearly disappeared from San Francisco Bay following [[overharvest]] during the [[California Gold Rush]] (1848-50s) and massive silting from [[hydraulic mining]] in [[California]]'s [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] (1850s-1880s). California's most valuable fishery from the 1880s-1910s was based on imported [[Eastern oyster|Atlantic oyster]]s, not the absent native. But in the 1990s, ''O. conchaphila'' once again appeared in San Francisco Bay near the [[Chevron Richmond Refinery]] in [[Richmond, California]]. ==Restoration efforts== Species restoration projects for the Olympia oyster funded by the US Government are active in [[Puget Sound]] and [[San Francisco Bay]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.publicaffairs.noaa.gov/releases2003/oct03/noaa03-r981.html|title=NOAA Awards $150,000 to Restore the Olympia Oyster in Puget Sound|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]]|date=October 23, 2003|accessdate=2010-09-11}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_15641891|title=Researchers working to restore population of Olympia oysters along California coast|date=August 1, 2010|accessdate=2010-09-11|publisher=San Jose Mercury News}}</ref> An active restoration project is taking place in [[Liberty Bay]], Washington.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.wa.nrcs.usda.gov/news/Highlights/HL26_WHIP.html|title=Recovery of the Olympia Oyster in Kitsap County|publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture]]|date=Spring, 2008|accessdate=2010-09-11}}</ref> This Puget Sound location is the home of an old and new Olympia oyster population. Intertidal areas with native oyster populations or evidence of past populations are strong candidates for re-introduction.<ref>{{cite web|title=Reestablishing Olympia Oyster Populations in Puget Sound, Washington|url=http://wsg.washington.edu/mas/pdfs/olyoysterlr.pdf|publisher=Washington Sea Grant}}</ref> The re-establishment of the population is currently threatened by the invasive Japanese oyster drill ''[[Ocinabrina inorata]]''. This species preys on the oysters by drilling a hole between the two valves and digesting the oyster's tissues. ''O. inorata'' is a threat to the oyster especially in areas with low populations of the mussel ''[[Mytilis]]''. The Nature Conservancy of Oregon also has an ongoing restoration project at [[Netarts Bay]], Oregon.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.nature.org/wherewework/northamerica/states/oregon/about/art18732.html|title=Returning oysters to the bay|publisher=[[The Nature Conservancy]]|accessdate=2010-09-11}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} {{Edible molluscs}} [[Category:Ostreidae]] [[Category:Molluscs of the Pacific Ocean]] [[Category:Molluscs of North America]] [[Category:Western North American coastal fauna]] [[Category:Fauna of California]] [[Category:Edible molluscs]] [[Category:Commercial molluscs]] [[Category:Seafood in Native American cuisine]] [[fr:Ostreola]]
